html.p: What: pastes two result sets together

ol.li: Does it in a "fairly dumb" way
But that's OK, there's no way to be smart about it
Columns that are in both sets of data are filled out.
Columns that are only on one side or the other will have blanks from 'the other side'

html.p: Why: While it's not the best command, there are times when it's the right one to use. Two data, *completely* unrelated, especially if one or both are relatively small. And by "completely unrelated" I mean that specifically, like 'from search' and 'from a datagen/makeresults'.
So What: IMO it's an overused command. It's often better to do the big "pile o' data" then stats it to group it.

The data we are using for this command -
Data 1 - a previous makeresults:
Data 2 - an inputlookup we built earlier. To build this see outputlookup.
While yours may differ slightly, that data for us is:

html.tt: | makeresults format=json data="[{\"name\":\"John\", \"age\":35}, {\"name\":\"Sarah\", \"age\":39}]" | append [ | inputlookup rdf_cars.csv ]
html.p: You'll see all the columns from both sides.

search.query: | makeresults format=json data="[{\"name\":\"John\", \"age\":35}, {\"name\":\"Sarah\", \"age\":39}]" | append [ | inputlookup rdf_cars.csv ]
